rules.name: Simple Explanations
rules.description: Always explain everything in simple terms that a 14-year-old would understand
rules.rule: When explaining technical concepts, code, or processes, use simple language, analogies, and step-by-step explanations that would be clear to a 14-year-old. Avoid jargon and complex technical terms without explaining them first. Use examples and comparisons to everyday things when possible. Always respond to the user in English.

rules.name: Dutch UI for Huurly Project
rules.description: Use Dutch language specifically for Huurly project user interface elements
rules.rule: When working on the Huurly project and creating, modifying, or suggesting user interface elements (buttons, labels, messages, form fields, navigation, etc.), always use Dutch language. This includes error messages, success messages, placeholders, tooltips, and any text that users will see in the Huurly application interface. Continue to respond to the user in English, but make the UI elements Dutch.

rules.name: Self-Improvement Through Mistake Analysis
rules.description: Create new rules when mistakes are identified to prevent similar errors in the future
rules.rule: When I notice I've made a mistake or the user points out an error in my reasoning, I must: 1) Acknowledge the mistake clearly, 2) Analyze WHY the mistake happened (root cause), 3) Create a specific rule to prevent this type of mistake in the future, 4) Add that rule to this rules file. This creates a continuous learning loop that makes me smarter and more efficient over time.

rules.name: Always Check Git History Before Making Branch Recommendations
rules.description: Examine git log and branch relationships before suggesting merge strategies
rules.rule: Before making any recommendations about git branches, merging, or repository management, I must first run 'git log --oneline --graph --all' to understand the actual branch relationships and commit history. Never assume branch relationships or make merge recommendations without first examining the git history. This prevents incorrect advice about which branches contain which changes.

rules.name: Continuous Development Flow
rules.description: NEVER stop development flow after phase completions or commits
rules.rule: After completing any phase, commit, or major milestone, I must IMMEDIATELY proceed to the next logical step without requiring manual intervention or stopping. This includes: 1) After phase completion → immediately begin next phase, 2) After commits → continue with next task in sequence, 3) After documentation → move directly to implementation, 4) No artificial stops or completion-only summaries. This rule has CRITICAL enforcement level and prevents workflow interruptions that require manual mode switching.
